author: ajsutton
content:
That kind of analysis requires syncing all available chains though.  Given the attacker can create a huge number of chains at very low cost,  your node is now susceptible to a DOS attack.
Also, how did you decide what the right ETH1 chain is? Given you have two beacon chains, both of which are pointing to different Eth1 chains, how do you know which is right? (especially post-merge)
How do you know which chain the genesis validators double voted on? They have precisely one vote on each chain so you'd have to downscore both chains equally.
You can create heuristics to help guess the right chain but they either don't provide any real guarantee or are prohibitively expensive.  Otherwise we'd put them in the fork choice rules and not be limited to weak subjectivity. 
Most often those heuristics mean trusting your network peers in aggregate - ie trusting that you have a good enough view of the network that the majority of peers aren't colluding against you. That actually works out much better than it sounds (eth1 fast sync depends on exactly that assumption or it too can be convinced to sync the wrong chain and get stuck there).

author: ajsutton
content: Also worth noting, if you have a heuristic that will tell you which chain is the right one, you can trivially confirm that the snapshot you have is from that chain.  You have to pay whatever cost the heuristic requires but get to skip all the work to sync beyond that.

content:
> That kind of analysis requires syncing all available chains though.  Given the attacker can create a huge number of chains at very low cost,  your node is now susceptible to a DOS attack.

An open system often is susceptible to a DoS attack. Just remember Prysm Cloudflare case. Good thing that there often is a way to fight it.

> Also, how did you decide what the right ETH1 chain is? Given you have two beacon chains, both of which are pointing to different Eth1 chains, how do you know which is right? (especially post-merge)

If the node can't see a canonical chain older than the follow distance then I don't think it's even worth talking about trusted artifacts.

> How do you know which chain the genesis validators double voted on? They have precisely one vote on each chain so you'd have to downscore both chains equally.
You can create heuristics to help guess the right chain but they either don't provide any real guarantee or are prohibitively expensive.  Otherwise, we'd put them in the fork choice rules and not be limited to weak subjectivity.

As I mentioned above you can analyze the deposit logs and identify the attackers there.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: We can proceed these debates forever as you can always pull some new detail that I will need to spend time to find a way to solve it. It's not productive. Let's lift this discussion to a higher level. My point is that the attacks are known and PoS is a fantastic protocol for figuring out who is responsible for it when we have an extremely high participation rate. In other words, if you have all the facts (not only on-chain facts) on the table you can identify which chain is made by using an attack. However, what you are trying to prove is the opposite. You are trying to pull the details that would bust this core theory. In my understanding, you can't succeed. So what you can do now - come with a theory that proves a possibility to pull out of the blue a valid (in your terms) alternative chain without using any attack, so then one can't justify which chain is made by an attacker based on all the facts (not only on-chain facts). You need to prove that it's possible to make an alternative chain without anyone cheating. But if you can prove this, then you bust the entire PoS.
